item.description:
24 City
5:30 — 7:20 pm
Thursday, August 27, 2009
Remis Auditorium

An experimental fiction-nonfiction hybrid, the film follows the transformation of a state-owned factory building into a luxury, high-rise apartment complex. The lives of six retired factory workers—living monuments of the era of Mao's China, when the country turned into a global power—are supplemented by monologues delivered by professional actors including Joan Chen, to create an oral history of post-revolutionary China. Like Zhang-ke's previous film Still Life, 24 City is artfully composed, rich in offbeat details, and punctuated with pop songs. An ambivalent exercise in Communist nostalgia as well as a moving collective portrait, the film was a New York Times critic's pick. In Mandarin and Shanghainese with English subtitles.

Named by James Naremore of Film Quarterly as the #1 Film of the Year, 2008 (My Winnipeg was #2)

From the 89% rottontomatoes rating: A masterful new documentary from Jia Zhang-ke – "Not only is the 38-year-old director the most prominent Chinese filmmaker of his generation, he also has come to assume the role of witness and conscience in a society characterized by rapid modernization and a growing amnesia." (Dennis Lim, LA Times, 2008) – 24 City recounts the dramatic and thunderous fall of the state-owned Factory 420, exploring both its physical demolition and its powerful symbolic echo of a half-century of communist rule.

Lots to talk about following the film. As this will be a weeknight, please indicate whether you can stay for the post film discussion at a nearby eatery.
